## a.

The goal of this task is to explain what an equity carve-out is.

***What is an equity carve-out?***

An **equity carve-out** is when a parent company first creates a separate company being its only owner. Next, the parent company organizes an **Initial Public Offering** (IPO) in which a fraction, possibly $20$ percent or so, of the parent’s stock, is sold to the public, creating a publicly held company.

***Why might a firm wish to do one?*** A firm might do an equity carve-out ***when it has a large operating unit and it wants that operating unit to run separately from the parent company***. In addition, ***when a company wants to capitalize on a new business activity that is not part of its main operations***.

## b.
The goal of this task is to explain what a split-up is.

***What is a split-up?***

**A split-up** occurs when a company splits itself into two or more new companies. Shareholders have their shares in the old company exchanged for shares in the new company.

***Why might a firm choose to do one?*** Split-ups are often publicized as a way of “unlocking” value, implicating a situation where *the whole is worth less than the sum of the parts*. In other words, *** a firm might choose to do a split-up when the value of the company if splits-up is expected to be higher than the entire company without splitting, ***. Also, in the case of diversified companies, splitting up and creating different companies according to the new and old activities it develops can be a good option.
